column4: # empty /etc/crontab in case there are only old regular jobs^Jcp -a /etc/crontab /etc/crontab.rpmsave^Jsed -e '/^01 \* \* \* \* root run-parts \/etc\/cron\.hourly/d'\^J  -e '/^02 4 \* \* \* root run-parts \/etc\/cron\.daily/d'\^J  -e '/^22 4 \* \* 0 root run-parts \/etc\/cron\.weekly/d'\^J  -e '/^42 4 1 \* \* root run-parts \/etc\/cron\.monthly/d' /etc/crontab.rpmsave > /etc/crontab^Jexit 0

# Save the current service runlevel info^J# User must manually run systemd-sysv-convert --apply crond^J# to migrate them to systemd targets^J/usr/bin/systemd-sysv-convert --save crond^J^J# The package is allowed to autostart:^J/bin/systemctl enable crond.service >/dev/null 2>&1^J^J/sbin/chkconfig --del crond >/dev/null 2>&1 || :^J/bin/systemctl try-restart crond.service >/dev/null 2>&1 || :^J/bin/systemctl daemon-reload >/dev/null 2>&1 || :
# changes in pam, glibc or libselinux can make crond crash^J# when it calls pam^J/bin/systemctl try-restart crond.service >/dev/null 2>&1 || :

# Save the current service runlevel info^J# User must manually run systemd-sysv-convert --apply firewalld^J# to migrate them to systemd targets^J/usr/bin/systemd-sysv-convert --save firewalld >/dev/null 2>&1 ||:^J^J# Run these because the SysV package being removed won't do them^J/sbin/chkconfig --del firewalld >/dev/null 2>&1 || :^J/bin/systemctl try-restart firewalld.service >/dev/null 2>&1 || :
